solution.p: The 2006 general Social Survey asked a large number of people how much time they spent watching TV each day. The mean number of hours was 4.4 with a standard deviation of 2.8. Assume that in a sample of 54 teenagers, the sample standard deviation of daily TV time is 2.8 hours, and that the population of TV watching times is normally distributed. Under 5 significance level can you conclude that the population standard deviation of TV watching times for teenagers is the same as 2.8?

Procedure: In the question, look for the keywords such as mean/average, proportion/percentage, variance/standard deviation! In this case, we have "standard deviation of TV watching times for teenagers", thus we are going to perform One variance ;967;sup2 Hypothesis Test.
Assumptions (select everything that applies): For One variance ;967;sup2 Hypothesis Test,

ul.li: the sample must be assumed to be a simple random sample.
the assumption "population standard deviation is unknown" is necessary for the one mean T procedure, but since it is technically satisfied we must select it as well.

The alternative hypothesis \displaystyle{H}_{{a}} : \displaystyle\sigma^{{2}}\ne{2.8}^{{2}} and the test is Two-Tailed
